Molybdenum diselenide(MoSe2) has attracted great interest as a promising nonprecious metal catalyst for hydrogen evolution reaction(HER). However, scarce catalytic sites and unsatisfactory electrocatalytic activity seriously impede its practical application. Single- and dual-atom catalysts play a crucial role in catalyzing of HER due to their unique electronic properties, highest atom utilization and synergistic effects. Herein, we screen a series of single- and dual-atom 3d-metals(Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn) doping MoSe2 as potential HER electrocatalysts based on density functional theory calculations. All 3d-metals doping MoSe2 exhibit highly thermodynamically and electrochemical stabilities, which show significantly promoting adsorption-activity by 3d-metals dopants, due to synergistic interaction between active Se site and neighboring 3d-metals dopants. Specially, we screen out that dual Cu-Co-MoSe2 shows the best HER activity with low overpotential(only 30 mV), markedly lower than single Co-MoSe2(360 mV) and crystal Pt(90 mV), indicating promising candidate for non-noble metal HER catalyst. Furthermore, we find descriptors of Δdp and ICOHP can well predict materials’ HER performance and exhibit linear relationship with H-binding strength. This study will provide in-depth understanding for designing and screening of high-efficiency MoSe2-based catalysts for HER. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal doping MoSe2 Hydrogen evolution reaction Descriptor Density functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) as the vital step of water electrolysis have been triggered enormous research effort over the past decades, because H2 production is recognized as the potential renewable resources to replace fossile fuels in the future energy supply [1-3]. Traditional Pt-based noble metal catalysts are still recognized as the best electrocatalysts for HER in the cathodes reaction. However, high-cost and insufficient reserves of Pt-based noble metal restrict their wide applications in HER. Therefore, it is urgently demanded to develop alternate HER electrocatalysts with low-cost, high catalytic activity and stability based on non-noble metals alternatives [4-12]. Recently, earth-abundant transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) such as MoS2, MoTe2, MoSe2 and WSe2 have emerged as potential candidates for electrocatalysis due to unique structure, high surface area and favorable electrochemical properties [13-20]. In particular, molybdenum diselenide (MoSe2) as a promising alternative electrocatalyst has attracted great interest for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) due to the distinct physical and chemical properties and potential in energy applications [21-23]. However, the application of MoSe2 is seriously impeded due to low conductivity and scarce catalytic sites of MoSe2, result in high overpotential and unsatisfactory catalytic activity [24]. Therefore, exploring effective strategies to modify and improve the electrochemical properties has become the focus of the interest. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have received wide attention in catalysis since it was first put forward by Zhang et al. [25,26] in 2011, due to their unique electronic structure and the highest atom utilization [27-33]. Recently, some studies on MoSe2 SACs have been reported for elctrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction and showed high activity [34,35]. Qian et al. [36] reported that single Zn-doped MoSe2 enrich the number of catalytic active sites and possess better HER performance compared with pure MoSe2. Jain et al. [37] studied single transition metal(Fe, Co, Ni, Mn) doped MoSe2 for HER performance, which demonstrates Ni-MoSe2 exhibit good HER activity, but Co-MoSe2 are still insufficiently to effectively active the pristine MoSe2 basal plane, result in unsatisfied HER activity. Under this circumstance, dual-atom catalysts (DACs) with intriguing catalytic properties have recently emerged as a further expansion to the family of SACs, which have the potential to meet higher active requirement [26,38-43]. A number of dual-atom catalysts (DACs) have been demonstrated as a cheap and promising strategy to tune the adsorption properties of H and promote HER activity, due to synergy effect on dual atoms to activate particular chemical bond of catalyst and optimize the HER catalytic performance, which go beyond the limitation of conventional bulk and nanoparticle catalysts [44-47]. Xu et al. [48] reported that introducing Te or Se dopant to B-MoS2 SAC further promote the OH* desorption and show excellent HER performances with lower overpotential of 61 and 68 mV at 10 mA cm−2 comparing to B-MoS2. Zhang et al. [49] reported that incorporating Ir and Mo dual-atom on carbon nanotubes lead to enhanced HER electrochemical activity with overpotential of only 15 mV at 0.95 mA cm−2, which is 14.4 times of those for single Ir/C. However, there are limited reports on studying active DACs of non-noble metal catalyst for HER, especially for studies on MoSe2-based DACs much less. A large number of studies for screening and optimizing MoSe2 DACs are necessary. As reported single Co-doped MoSe2 is still insufficiently to effectively active the pristine MoSe2 basal plane, result in unsatisfied HER activity [37]. We hypothesize that when another non-noble 3d-metal dopant is further introduced to be the active site for H* adsorption, it may tune adsorption properties of hydrogen and the HER performance. Additionally, determined active site of catalysts and understanding the synergy mechanisms between paired metal atoms to active the basal plane are still unclear. In this paper, a series of single- and dual-atom 3d-metals doping MoSe2 as potential HER catalysts were systematically investigate based on vander Waals-corrected density functional theory (DFT-D3) calculations. We considered the geometries, electronic properties and HER performances of non-noble 3d-metals (Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn) doping to active neighboring Se atoms in MoSe2 basal plane. Our results provide an understanding for the design and development of high-efficiency MoSe2-based dual-atom catalysts for HER. 2 Computational methods All the spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculation were carried out using the Vienna ab initio simulation Package (VASP) [50]. The projector-augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotentials and the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of the Perdue-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correclation functional were employed to describe the electron-ion and exchange-correlation interactions, respectively [51,52]. A 5 × 5 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack mesh was adoped for the k-point sampling of Brilliouin zone, with a cutoff energy of 500 eV for the plane wave expansion. Convergence tolerance were adopted to be 10−5 eV/atom of energyies and 0.01 eV/Å of forces, respectively. DFT-D3 calculation were employed to calculated the van der Waals (vdW) interaction [53,54]. The lattice parameters of monolayer MoSe2 were calculated to be a = b = 3.29 Å, which are consistent with previous experimentally results [55]. The MoSe2-based planes are simulated by a periodic slab with 4 × 4 supercell, with a vacuum space of 15 Å to avoid the periodic boundary interactions, which is consistent with previous works [56,57]. During structural optimization, all the internal coordinates were fully relaxed in all directions. The adsorption energy of hydrogen on dual TM-Co-MoSe2 catalysts were calculated as follows: (1) Δ E H = E H * − E * − 1 / 2 E H 2 where EH* and E* represents total energy of the H adsorption on dual TM-Co-MoSe2 and clean dual TM-Co-MoSe2, respectively, while EH2 represents total energy of H2 in gas phase. The HER activity of the catalyst was evaluated by calculating the free energy change of the adsorption atomic hydrogen (ΔG H ), which is defined as: (2) Δ G H = Δ E H + Δ E Z P E − T Δ S H Where ΔEZPE is the zero-point energy difference between the adsorbed state of dual TM-Co-MoSe2 system and the gas-phase state, the ΔSH is obtained by ΔSH ≅ −1/2 S H 2 0 , and the S H 2 0 is the entropy of H2 in gas phase at standard condition ( S H 2 0 ∼ 130 J·mol·K−1) [58]. The formation energies [59] were calculated as follows: (3) E f = ( E X ( Y ) − M o S e 2 − A μ S e − B μ M o − μ X − μ Y ) / n Where EX(Y) − MoSe2 is the energy of 3d-metallic single- and dual-atom MoSe2 catalysts, μX and μY is the chemical potential of the doped 3d transition metal atom(TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn) in their bulk crystal, respectively. μSe, μMo is the chemical potential of Se and Mo in their bulk crystal, respectively.A and B represent the number of Se and Mo atoms, and n is the total number of the atoms in EX(Y) − MoSe2 . The dissolution potential [60,61] is defined as (4) E b = E X ( Y ) − MoSe 2 − E V − MoSe 2 − μ X − μ Y (5) U diss = U diss ( metal , bulk ) o − E b / ( e N e * N M ) where Eb is the binding energies of 3d-metallic single- and dual-atom MoSe2 catalysts, E X(Y) − MoSe2 is the energy of single- and dual-atom doping MoSe2 catalysts, and EV − MoSe2 is the energy of defective MoSe2; μX and μY is the chemical potential of the doped 3d transition metal atom(TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn) in their bulk crystal, respectively. Udiss o(metal, bulk) and Ne are the standard dissolution potential (pH = 0) of bulk metal in aqueous solution and the number of electrons involved in dissolution, respectively. NM indicates the number of metal atoms. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Dopant structures and H-adsorption on single-doped MoSe2 (TM-MoSe2) catalysts For the pursuit of triggering HER activity on MoSe2, a series of 3d transition metal atoms (Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn) were introduced into pristine MoSe2, where transition metals constitute Mo atom (Fig. 1 a). We firstly evaluated the thermodynamic and electrochemical stabilities of these single-doped MoSe2 (TM-MoSe2) by the formation energies (Ef) and dissolution potentials (Udiss). According to Eqs. (4)–(6), TM-MoSe2 with value of Ef< 0 eV are regarded as thermodynamically stable, while materials with value of Udiss> 0 eV vs SHE are electrochemically stable. The corresponding values of Ef and Udiss are listed in Fig. 1a. Our results show that Ef value for all the single-doped MoSe2 (Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn) are negative, indicating exothermic and high thermodynamically stable. As for Udiss, nine TM-MoSe2 (Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn) value are positive vs SHE, indicating electrochemically stable and feasibility of our approach, except Sc-MoSe2 ruled out due to the negative Udiss value. Next, we investigated the effect of single TM-dopants on the HER activity by the change in free energy of H-adsorption (ΔGH). According to the Sabatier principle [62,63], an ideal adsorption free energy of H atom (ΔGH) on catalyst should be close to 0 eV where hydrogen adsorption own the most optimal strength for hydrogen evolution in the low overpotential range. We found that the Se atom neighboring the single TM-dopant atom are the most favorable H-adsorption site. Fig. 1b displays the adsorption free energy of H atom (ΔGH). The results show that H adsorption on the pristine is greatly unfavorable (ΔGH = 1.94 eV). After single 3d transition metal atom doping, value of ΔGH for TM-MoSe2 are in the range from −0.11 to 1.47 eV, which are greatly decreased than that of pristine MoSe2, indicating H adsorption becomes more favorable. Among them, for the case of Ti, V, Sr, Fe, Mn and Cr, the H adsorption Gibbs free energy are significantly decreased (0.60, 0.64, 0.67, 0.87, 1.15 and 1.47 eV, respectively), but the resulting adsorption strength are still greatly unfavorable to triggering HER activity at low overpotentials. While for the Ni-MoSe2, Cu-MoSe2 and Zn-MoSe2, H adsorption becomes thermodynamically favorable with value of ΔGH close to 0 (−0.11, 0.11, 0.19 eV, respectively), indicating being promising candidates for non-noble metal HER catalyst. 3.2 Dopant structures and H-adsorption on dual TM-Co-doped MoSe2 catalysts According to above analysis, single Co-doped MoSe2 has moderate H adsorption energy (ΔGH = 0.36 eV) which have significantly improved the HER performance, compared with pristine MoSe2 (1.94 eV). However, it is still insufficient to effectively active MoSe2, result in unsatisfied HER activity, which is consistent with previous work [37]. Therefore, we hypothesize that when another non-noble 3d-metal dopant is further introduced to single Co-MoSe2 being the active site for H* adsorption, which may further optimize the hydrogen adsorption properties and the HER performance. Additionally, determining active site of catalysts and understanding the synergy mechanisms between paired metal atoms to active the basal plane are still unclear. We firstly constructed the dual TM-Co-MoSe2 catalysts by 3d transition metal (Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Ni, Cu and Zn) and Co substituting Mo atoms in the MoSe2 monolayer, respectively (Fig. 2 ). To determine the optimal structure of these dual TM-Co-MoSe2 (TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Ni, Cu and Zn), three possible configurations are considered: TM and Co dopants share the same Se atom (Ⅰ), two dopants in armchair direction (Ⅱ) and in zigzag direction seperated by one Mo atom (Ⅲ), respectively (Fig. 3 a). As shown in Fig. 3a, we found that the most stable structure is the configurations Ⅰ for all the dual TM-Co-doped MoSe2 (TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Ni, Cu and Zn). So we will focus on configuration Ⅰ for further exploration of structures, electronic properties and HER activities. In order to examined the thermodynamic and electrochemical stabilities of these dual TM-Co-doped MoSe2, formation energies and dissolution potentials were calculated and are listed in Fig. 3b. The results show that all the values of formation energies are negative, indicating the formation of our designed dual TM-Co-MoSe2 systems are exothermic and thermodynamically stable. While the values of dissolution potential for all the TM-Co-MoSe2 are positive vs SHE, indicating electrochemically stable and the feasibility of our approach. To further verify the kinetic stability of dual TM-Co-MoSe2 catalysts, Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulation with Nosé algorithm [64] were further carried out under temperatures of 300 K for 10 ps with a time step of 1 fs (Fig. S1). Surprisingly, all the dual-atom systems keep the structure integrity and the amplitude of the energy fluctuation is small near equilibrium state. It is indicated that all the dual TM-Co-MoSe2 are dynamically stable at room temperature and are feasible for practical application. To examine HER activities of these dual TM-Co-MoSe2 (TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Ni, Cu and Zn), we investigated H-adsorption performance on their basal plane. As shown in Fig. S2, the H atom showed location preference at the Se site neighboring between TM atom and Co atom for all the dual-atom catalysts. According to the Sabatier principle [62,63], an ideal adsorption free energy of H atom (ΔGH) on catalyst should be close to 0 eV where hydrogen adsorption own the most optimal strength for hydrogen evolution in the low overpotential range. To investigate the effect of adsorbed hydrogen on the different dual-atom MoSe2 catalysts, we further calculated the adsorption free energy of H atom (ΔGH) on the dual TM-Co-doped MoSe2 as shown in Fig. 4 a. The results show that ΔGH of all the dual TM-Co-MoSe2 (Sc∼Zn) catalysts are in the range from −0.21 to 0.45 eV, which are all significantly smaller than that of pristine MoSe2 (ΔGH = 1.94 eV). It is indicated that the H adsorption strength of these dual-atom catalysts (DACs) are much stronger than that of pristine MoSe2. Therefore, dual-atom TM-Co doping can bring catalytic active sites and trigger HER activities of MoSe2 basal plane. While comparing with the single Co-MoSe2 (ΔGH = 0.36 eV), the H adsorption Gibbs free energy for Ni-Co-MoSe2 (−0.21 eV), Cu-Co-MoSe2 (0.03 eV) and Zn-Co-MoSe2 (0.08 eV) are greatly stronger than the single Co-MoSe2. But the H adsorption free energy for Ti-Co-MoSe2 (0.39 eV) and Sc-Co-MoSe2 (0.45 eV) are weaker than that of single Co-MoSe2 (0.36 eV). Therefore, it is suggested another 3d-metal dopant introduced to single Co-MoSe2 can further effectively active neighboring Se atoms and tuning the HER catalytic activity of Co-MoSe2. Notably, the ΔGH of the Cu-Co-MoSe2 (0.03 eV) and Zn-Co-MoSe2 (0.08 eV) are markedly lower than Co-MoSe2 (0.35 eV) and single crystal Pt (0.09 eV), indicating being promising candidates for noble metal HER catalyst. We further investigated the effect of the content ratio between Cu and Co on HER activity by using Cu1Co1, Cu1Co2, Cu2Co1, Cu1Co3, Cu3Co1 and Cu2Co2-MoSe2. The results showed that ΔGH for content ratio of Cu and Co at 1:1, 2:1, 1:2, 2:2, 3:1 and 1:3 is 0.03, 0.09, −0.17, −0.23, −0.35 and −0.96 eV, respectively (Fig. S3). The |ΔGH| are gradually increased with increasing content ratio of Cu and Co. Especially, the |ΔGH| of Cu1Co1-MoSe2 with low doping concentration is more closer to 0 eV, indicating the best HER activity. Additionally, comparing with the Cu2Co1 (0.09 eV) and Cu1Co2 (−0.17 eV), Cu3Co1 (−0.35 eV) and Cu1Co3 (−0.96 eV), H adsorption become more favorable at higher concentration of Cu. 3.3 Electronic properties and adsorption-activity relationship of dual TM-Co-MoSe2 catalysts To understand the effect of different dual-TM atoms doping on MoSe2, we analyzed the electronic properties of the dual TM-Co-MoSe2 catalysts. Fig. 4b displayed the partial density of states for a few representative case of dual TM-Co-MoSe2 catalysts, including Se 4p-state, Mo 4d-state, Co 4d-state and TM dopants 3d-state for pristine MoSe2, single Co-MoSe2, dual Co-Ti-MoSe2 and Co-Cu-MoSe2. It can be seen that before doping, pristine MoSe2 has a moderate band gap and there are no state appearing near the Fermi level in favour of H binding, suggesting the Se site is inert. While after introducing single Co atom in MoSe2 basal plane, electronic gap states appear to occurring near the Fermi level to be benefical for bonding with hydrogen. The gap-states are mainly originated from somewhat Se 4p-state and neighboring metal atoms d-states (Co 3d-state and Mo 4d-state), indicating stronger H bonding with the adjacent Se site compared to pristine MoSe2, which is consistent with above analysis of hydrogen adsorption free energy (Fig. 4a). When further incorporating Ti atom into single Co-MoSe2, similar to that of single Co-MoSe2, there are some electronic gap states originated from 3d-state of Co and Ti, Mo 4d-state and somewhat Se 4p-state near the Fermi level observed, indicated both of Se p-states and neibghboring metal atom d-states have close relationship to H adsorption performance. While for Cu atom further introduced into single Co-MoSe2, there are also some electronic gap states appearing near the Fermi level. But different from single Co-MoSe2 and Ti-Co-MoSe2, more obvious characteristic peaks of Se 4p-state are observed near the Fermi level, indicating more stronger H-Se binding strength in Cu-Co-MoSe2 system than single Co-MoSe2 and Ti-Co-MoSe2, which were consistent with above analysis of H-Se binding (Fig. 4a). Additionally, obvious electronic gap states from Se(4p)-Cu(3d), Se(4p)-Co(3d) and Se(4p)-Mo(4d) hybridization in the bandgap are also observed, suggested that the trend in H-Se binding strength can be revealed with the synergistic effect between Se p-state and neighboring metal d-states. So, the interband enegy separation between Se p-states and neighboring metal d-states (denoted as Δdp) were further investigated to find out what determine doping effect on the reactivity of different dual TM-Co-MoSe2 catalysts. The formular to calculated Δdp as follows [16,65,66]: (6) Δ dp = ε d − ε p = ∫ − 2 2 ε n d ∫ − 2 2 n d − ∫ − 2 2 ε n p ∫ − 2 2 n p Where the average d-band center (εd) of this limited integration range is over the d-orbital of all three metal atoms surrounding the Se atom. Fig. 5 shows some representative cases of the PDOS of Se atom and surrounding metal atoms, as well as the relationship to Δdp for pristine MoSe2, single Co-MoSe2, dual Co-Ti-MoSe2 and dual Co-Cu-MoSe2. As shown in Fig. 5, pristine MoSe2 has the largest Δdp value of 0.96 eV (Fig. 5a). While for single Co-MoSe2, significantly electronic gap states originated from Se p-state and surrounding Co and Mo d-state hybridization in the “bandgap” are observed. The smaller size of Co comparing with Mo lead to weaker interaction with adjacent Se. Corresponding H bind more stronger to adjacent Se with EH* of 0.03 eV vs 1.70 eV for MoSe2. It result in smaller Δdp of 0.46 eV comparing with MoSe2 (0.96 eV), indicating smaller interband energy separation leads to the strongest interacton of H-Se bond (EH* = 0.03 eV) (Fig. 5b). For the case of Ti-Co-MoSe2 with the slightly larger size of Ti compared to Mo, it has a slightly increased Δdp of 0.55 eV and slightly weaker EH* (0.06 eV) compared with single Co-MoSe2 (Fig. 5c). While for the case of Cu-Co-MoSe2, dopant to the smaller size of Cu generated gap states near the Fermi level, in which unoccupied d-states are available at the top of the valence band. It result in a significantly decreased Δdp of −0.11 eV and stronger EH* (−0.28 eV), indicating smaller interband energy separation leads to stronger hydrogen binding strength (Fig. 5d). Therefore, the results show that strong variation of activation degree by dual 3d-metal dopants with much more varied Δdp comparing with single Co-MoSe2. Synergistic effect between Se 4p-state and all neighboring three metals d-states at active site further effectively regulated the adsorption-activity in host MoSe2. Simlar analysis also have been proposed to elucidate this mechanism [16,65,66]. Concise descriptors play an important role in exploring high-performance catalysts easily. Thus, we further investigated the possible descriptors based Δdp, ICOHP and H adsorption free energy (ΔGH) for all the dual TM-Co-MoSe2 as shown in Fig. 6 . The correlation between the Δdp and the hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔGH) of dual TM-Co-MoSe2 (TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Ni, Cu and Zn) is shown in Fig. 6a. We can clearly see that the data points of Δdp are closely related to the ΔGH by a linear relationship, suggesting descriptor Δdp can well describe the HER performance, excluding Fe-Co-MoSe2. The positive slope manifests the smaller interband energy separations Δdp, the smaller the ΔGH value, the better the HER performance, which was consistent with above analysis of DOS and Δdp (Fig. 5). Therefore, Δdp value of active sites with smaller difference energy level between average d band center of all three metal atoms surrounding the active Se site and p band center of active Se site are benefit for H adsorption. Particularly, the degree of activation is understood from the changes of electronic properties between Se active site and neighboring three metals. However, in rare case Fe-Co-MoSe2, our descriptor is not quantitatively predictive. As fewer electron transfer from the neighboring three metals to Se atom (0.23 e) comparing with other DAC systems. The PDOS for the active Se atom and the average of neighboring three metals also show substantial Se-4p state located on both side of Fermi level, result in larger εd value (not shown). The fit line to the descriptor Δdp would suggest stronger adsorption strength and underestimate the promotion energy required for H-Se bond formation in case of Fe-Co-MoSe2 comparing with the DFT calculations. Next, the adsorption bonding characteristics between the Se active site and adsorbed H are analysed by the crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) (Fig. 7 ).The relationship between integrated crystal orbital Hamilton population (ICOHP) and ΔGH are further investigate(Fig. 6b). ICOHP is quantity expressing bond strength between atoms. The more negative the ICOHP is, the stronger the bond strength is. From Fig. 7, it can be clearly seen that after H adsorption on substrate, H atom has a strong interaction with the active Se site on dual TM-Co-MoSe2. For example, single Cu-Co is −2.7038, Ti-Co is −2.5734, Sc-Co is −2.5215. As shown in Fig. 6b, ICOHP is closely related to the ΔGH and R2 =0.81. The larger the ICOHP is, the larger the ΔGH value is. It is proved that the two descriptors of Δdp and ICOHP are responsible for the variation of hydrogen bonding strength on the different dual TM-Co-MoSe2 complexes, and can well predict the HER catalytic performance trend of these dual-atom catalyst. Finally, to further investigate the catalytic activity of these dual TM-Co-MoSe2 (TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Ni, Cu and Zn), we calculated exchange current densities(i0 ) for HER and plotted the volcano curve for all the dual TM-Co-MoSe2 electrocatalysts as shown in Fig. 8 . Here, exchanges current (i0 ) and the overpotential as a function of |∆GH| is calculated as follows [67]: (7) i 0 = − e k 0 1 1 + exp ( | Δ G H k bT | ) (8) η HER = − | Δ G H | e × 1 0 3 where T, kb, and k0 represented temperature, Boltzmann constant, and reaction rate constant at zero overpotential, respectively. The k0 value is set to 1 for illustrative purposes. As shown in Fig. 8, dual Cu-Co-MoSe2 (∆GH ≈ 0 eV) is located on the volcano peak with the highest HER i0 and the lowest overpotential, indicating the best catalytic region, according to the Sabatier principle [62]. When ∆GH > 0, H bonding strength is relatively weak, result in i0 increase with decreasing of ∆GH. While ∆GH < 0, H bonding strength is relatively strong, result in i0 decrease with decreasing of ∆GH. Therefore, based on the volcano analysis, we conclude that dual Cu-Co and Zn-Co dual-doped MoSe2 are highly promising candidates for enhancing the electrocatalytic activity of MoSe2 to HER. Dual Cu-Co-MoSe2 shows best HER activity with low overpotential (only 30 mV), markedly lower than previous works (crystal Pt (90 mV) [37], MoS2-MoSe2(175 mV) [68] and Ni-doped vertically aligned MoSe2(250 mV) [69]. 4 Conclusion Molybdenum diselenide (MoSe2) as a promising nonprecious metal catalyst has attracted great interest for electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). However, scarce catalytic sites and unsatisfactory catalytic activity seriously impedes its practical application. While single- and dual-atom catalyst (DACs) is effective strategy to trigger unique ability to activate particular chemical bond and promote excellent catalytic performance due to their unique electronic structure and the highest atom utilization. Thus, we screen a series of MoSe2-based catalysts by doping with single- and dual-atom 3d-metals(Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Ni, Cu and Zn) for efficient HER catalysts, and systematically investigate geometries, stabilities, electronic properties and HER performances based on density functional theory calculations. We demeonstrated that all the 3d-metal modified-MoSe2 catalysts are thermodynamically and electrochemical stable and easier for practical application, which show strong variation in the degree of activation by single- and dual 3d-metal dopants comparing with MoSe2 basal plane. Specially, we screened out that Cu-Co-MoSe2 shows best catalytic activity for HER with the overpotential of only 30 mV, markedly lower than the Co-MoSe2 single-atom catalyst (350 mV), and even lower than single crystal Pt catalyst (90 mV), indicating being the promising candidates for non-noble metal HER catalyst. To assist the screening of 3d transition metal to active single Co-MoSe2, we further performed electronic properties analysis on dual TM-Co-MoSe2 DACs. Synergistic effect between Se and all neighboring three metals at active site effectively promoted adsorption-activity of host MoSe2. Two descriptors of Δdp and ICOHP are found to exhibit linear relationship with the H bonding strength, which were responsible for the variation ability for H binding to reactive site, and further correlated with the trend of catalytic activity for dual-atom catalysts. The Δdp of active site with smaller difference of energy level between average d band center of all three metal atoms surrounding active Se site and p band center of Se atom are benefit for H adsorption. And the larger the ICOHP, the larger the ΔGH value. Therefore, it is indicated that two descriptors of Δdp and ICOHP can well predict the HER catalytic performance trend of these dual-atom catalysts. Our results provide an in-depth understanding for the activation and development of high-efficiency MoSe2-based catalysts for HER. However, experiments are also required to validate the synthesis feasibility and the electrochemical performance of these catalysts for HER. coredata.dc:description: Molybdenum diselenide(MoSe2) has attracted great interest as a promising nonprecious metal catalyst for hydrogen evolution reaction(HER). However, scarce catalytic sites and unsatisfactory electrocatalytic activity seriously impede its practical application. Single- and dual-atom catalysts play a crucial role in catalyzing of HER due to their unique electronic properties, highest atom utilization and synergistic effects. Herein, we screen a series of single- and dual-atom 3d-metals(Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn) doping MoSe2 as potential HER electrocatalysts based on density functional theory calculations. All 3d-metals doping MoSe2 exhibit highly thermodynamically and electrochemical stabilities, which show significantly promoting adsorption-activity by 3d-metals dopants, due to synergistic interaction between active Se site and neighboring 3d-metals dopants. Specially, we screen out that dual Cu-Co-MoSe2 shows the best HER activity with low overpotential(only 30 mV), markedly lower than single Co-MoSe2(360 mV) and crystal Pt(90 mV), indicating promising candidate for non-noble metal HER catalyst. Furthermore, we find descriptors of Δdp and ICOHP can well predict materials’ HER performance and exhibit linear relationship with H-binding strength. This study will provide in-depth understanding for designing and screening of high-efficiency MoSe2-based catalysts for HER.
